channel.title: Lisa Anders - questionable.quarto
channel.description: Making the most out of data

item.title: Peanut Butter Cucumber Salad
item.dc:creator: Aaron and Claire
item.description:
At a Glance

Don’t worry bout it :)

Ingredients

  • 2 English cucumbers
  • 2 garlic cloves
  • 1 green onion (optional)
  • 1 tbsp toasted sesame seeds, ground
  • Kosher salt, to taste

Dressing

  • 3 tbsp peanut butter
  • 1 tbsp Korean chili pepper flakes (gochugaru)
  • 1 tbsp soy sauce
  • 1/2 tbsp sugar
  • 2 tbsp lemon juice
  • 2 tsp toasted sesame oil

If you don’t have gochugaru you can use 0.5 tbs korean red chili powder and 1 tbs red chili flakes.

Instructions

  1. Trim off the ends of the cucumbers and cut them into bite-sized pieces. Transfer to a mixing bowl. Finely chop the garlic cloves and thinly slice the green onion (if using).
  2. Make the dressing: In a small container, combine all the dressing ingredients with the minced garlic. Mix until smooth and well combined.
  3. Pour the dressing over the cucumbers, add 1 tablespoon of freshly ground sesame seeds, and gently toss until everything is evenly coated. Taste and add more salt if needed. Enjoy!

Lisa’s notes

Serve with soy sauce chicken!

item.title: Johnny Cakes
item.dc:creator: Tasting History
item.description:
Ingredients

  • Bacon, however much you want to eat with your johnny cakes
  • 2 cups (300 g) fine cornmeal
  • 1 tablespoon molasses
  • 1 teaspoon salt
  • 2 tablespoons (30 g) unsalted butter
  • 3/4 cup (175 ml) boiling water, a bit more depending on your taste

Instructions

  1. Fry up your bacon however you like it and keep the grease in the pan. I used a cast iron pan for this, but a regular frying pan will also work.
  2. In a bowl, use your hands to mix the cornmeal, molasses, salt, and butter together.
  3. Add boiling water to the cornmeal mixture and use a spoon to stir until it’s all mixed in. The amount of water you add will depend on what texture you want for the cakes. Less water will make for a firmer cake, more water will make a thinner, more flexible cake. You want it to be thick enough for it to hold its shape; more of a dough than a batter.
  4. Form the dough into round cakes with your hands. The size is up to you. I made mine about 2 1/2 to 3 inches (6 1/2 to 7 1/2 cm) across.
  5. Heat the bacon grease in the pan over medium heat. If you don’t want to use bacon, you could use another type of fat like lard or butter. Carefully set the cakes in the hot grease and cook for about 3 minutes on one side, then flip and cook for 2 minutes on the other side, or until they’re nicely browned.
  6. Serve them forth with the bacon, and honey, syrup, or molasses if desired.

Lisa’s notes

Very different than pancakes and yet somehow feels just as special as a breakfast. I could see this working on days where I want something more substantial.

item.title: Mediterranean Rice with Beans
item.dc:creator: Natural Grocers
item.description:
Ingredients

1 cup White Basmati Rice

1 teaspoon Salt

1 teaspoon Ground Black Pepper

1 (15.5-ounce) can Great Northern Beans or Organic Garbanzo Beans, drained and rinsed

½ cup Pitted Kalamata Olives, roughly chopped

½ cup Pitted Green Olives, roughly chopped

1 cup Roasted Red Pepper Strips, roughly chopped

1 cup marinated or chopped artichoke hearts

2 garlic cloves

1 cup grape tomatoes sliced in half

2 cups vegetable broth

2 cups organic baby spinach roughly chopped (ignore is ok)

1/2 lemon

(Optional) Finely grated parsley

(Optional) Feta crumples

Instructions

  1. Preheat oven to 400

  2. Add the rice to a three-quart casserole dish (139

2-inchi Top with salt and pepper, beans, olives, red peppers, artichokes, garlic, tomatoes, and spinach Use tongs or a spoon to mix and distribute all the ingredients somewhat evenly

3 Pour the vegetable broth over the rice and vegetables Gently stir once more to evenly distribute

4 Bake uncovered for 40 minutes or until the rice is tender

  1. Remove the casserole dish from the oven and squeeze the lemon over the top. Add optional toppings as desired before serving Leftovers can be refrigerated for up to three days (this dish is also delicious cold)

Lisa’s notes

item.title: Dairy free pesto with almonds
item.dc:creator: The Granola Diaries
item.description:
Ingredients

  • 1 Big Handful Basil roughly 1 cup
  • 1 Cup Spinach - or can add another cup of basil
  • ½ Cup Olive Oil
  • 1 Garlic clove - or like 4 or 5 if you like garlic
  • Juice of ½ - 1 lemon
  • ¼ teaspoon Salt
  • ⅓ Cup Almonds

Instructions

  • Add all ingredients except almonds to a food processor. Pulse for 30 seconds - 1 minute, until everything is combined.
  • Add the almonds and process for a few seconds at a time, until they are incorporated into the sauce. Do this more or less, depending on the consistency you like your pesto. Less pulsing will lead to chunkier pesto.
  • Pour in a bowl for dipping, or directly on warm pasta, or spread on a sandwich. Store in an airtight container in the fridge for up to a week, or freeze in an ice cube tray for up to 6 months.

Lisa’s notes

Good luck having enough that you need to store leftovers!

item.title: Rice Pudding
item.dc:creator: Lisa and Jesse original
item.description:
Ingredients

  • 1 c shitty rice
  • 2 c water
  • 1 c milk
  • Cardamom
  • Chinese 5 spice, cinnamon, or other spices of choice
  • Salt

Instructions

  • Add raisins, some more milk and water, the liquid from a can of coconut milk, and the rice
  • Cook
  • Add the coconut cream solid
  • Add sugar to serve

Lisa’s notes

We bought this terrible rice at Costco and it just never ends. I’m assuming it’s split rice, and it just does not hold fluid. This is pretty much the only way to use it where it isn’t gross.

item.title: Chocolate Lemon Mousse
item.dc:creator: Catherine Perez from Peaceful Kitchen
item.description:
At a Glance

SERVES 6

PREP TIME: 15 MINUTES

COOKING TIME: 3 MINUTES

Ingredients

5 ounces 70% dark chocolate bars

12 ounces (340g) silken tofu, brought to room temperature

3 tablespoons maple syrup

2 tablespoons unsweetened Dutch-processed cocoa powder

1 teaspoon espresso powder

Zest of 1 lemon, plus more for topping

1/2 teaspoon kosher salt

Flaky sea salt, for sprinkling

Instructions

Start by melting the chocolate. To melt the chocolate in the microwave, break the chocolate bars into smaller pieces in a small microwave-safe bowl. Place in the microwave for 30 seconds, then stir. Microwave the chocolate in 15-second intervals, stirring each time until the chocolate is fully melted (for me this took 3 15-second intervals). - We used a toaster oven to melt the chocolate.

Place the tofu, maple syrup, cocoa powder, espresso powder, lemon zest, and kosher salt into a high-speed blender or food processor. Blend the mixture until completely smooth, scraping down the sides as needed.

Pour in all the melted chocolate and continue to blend until com-pletely smooth, scraping down the sides as needed.

Divide the mousse between 6 small dessert glasses. Place the mousse in the fridge for at least 30 minutes to firm up. If making ahead, place the mousse in small airtight jars and store in the fridge for up to 3 days. To serve, allow the mousse to sit out at room temperature for a few minutes, then top with extra lemon zest and a sprinkle of flaky salt, then enjoy.

Lisa’s notes

Delicious treat.

item.title: Lentil rice
item.dc:creator: Catherine Perez from Peaceful Kitchen
item.description:
At a Glance

SERVES 3

PREP TIME: 15 MINUTES

COOKING TIME: 20 MINUTES

Ingredients

FOR THE CRISPY LENTILS

115-ounce can (or 1/2 cups cooked) small brown lentils or French lentils, drained and rinsed

1 teaspoon garlic powder

teaspoon onion powder

1 tablespoon avocado oll

FOR THE FRIED RICE

12 tablespoons tamari

1 tablespoon maple syrup

vegetable bouillon cube, crushed, or ½ teaspoon vegetable bouillon paste

1 teaspoon grated fresh ginger

1 to 2 tablespoons avocado oil

2 scallions, white and green parts thinly sliced

small yellow onion, diced Kosher salt to taste

3 garlic cloves, crushed with a garlic press

1 medium zucchini, diced

3 cups leftover cold white jasmine rice

Instructions

PREPARE THE CRISPY LENTILS

Preheat the oven to 425°F. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.

If using canned lentils, drain and rinse them well, then place on a clean kitchen towel and pat dry. Add the lentils to the prepared baking sheet and top with the garlic powder, onion powder, and oil. Toss to evenly coat, then spread them out in a single layer on the baking sheet and place in the oven for 15 minutes, tossing halfway through.

PREPARE THE FRIED RICE

While the lentils roast, prepare your sauce. In a small bowl, combine the tamari, 1 tablespoon water, maple syrup, bouillon cube, and ginger and whisk together until the bouillon cube is mostly dissolved, then set aside.

Place a wok or a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the oil, and once hot, add the white parts of the scallions and the onion along with a pinch of salt and sauté for 2 to 3 minutes until softened.

Add the garlic and zucchini and continue to sauté for an additional 2 to 3 minutes or until the zucchini starts to get golden around the edges.

Stir in the rice and start to break it up with your spatula and mix it into the vegetables. Pour in the prepared sauce and continue sautéing until the rice is evenly coated.

Add the roasted lentils and stir them into the rice, mixing until evenly distributed. Remove from the heat and serve, garnishing with the re-maining green parts of the scallions as desired.

Lisa’s notes

item.title: Sesame ginger chicken wraps
item.dc:creator: Kylie Sakaida from So Easy So Good
item.description:
At a Glance

Serves 4

Total time: 15 minutes

Ingredients

Dressing

2 tablespoons peeled and grated fresh ginger (about a 2-inch piece)

2 garlic cloves, minced

3 tablespoons reduced-sodium soy sauce

2 tablespoons rice vinegar

1 tablespoon toasted sesame oil

Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

Wraps

3 cups shredded rotisserie chicken

3 cups shredded cabbage or coleslaw mix

1 cup shredded carrots

1/3 cup finely chopped fresh cilantro or mint

4 (10-inch) flour, corn, or almond flour tortillas

Instructions

Make the dressing: In a large bowl, whisk together the ginger, garlic, soy sauce, rice vinegar, sesame oil. a pinch of salt, and a few twists of black pepper.

Make the wraps: To the bowl of dressing, add the chicken, cabbage, shredded carrots, and cilantro and mix together until well combined

Stack the tortillas on a microwave-safe plate and microwave for 45 seconds to help make them more pliable.

Lay the tortillas out on a work surface. Dividing evenly, top the bottom half of the tortillas with the chicken mixture. Roll up the wrap by folding the left and right sides of the tortillas over the filling.

Fold the bottom flap over the filling and roll the wrap closed. Slice in half on the diagonal and serve.

Lisa’s notes

item.title: Tahini Sweet Potato and Chickpea Bowls
item.dc:creator: Kylie Sakaida
item.description:
Ingredients

  • 2 sweet potatoes, peeled and cut into 1/2 inch cubes

  • 3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil

  • 1/2 teaspoon chili powder

  • 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt

  • 1 (15-ounce) can chickpeas, drained and rinsed

  • 1/2 teaspoon garlic powder

  • 1/2 teaspoon paprika

  • 4 cups chopped kale or aragula

  • 1/2 cup Tahini Turmeric Lemon Dressing (recipe follows)

  • 1/2 cup sunflower seeds, for garnish

  • Chopped fresh parsley or cilantro, for garnish

  • Lime wedges, for squeezing (optional)

  • Chicken (optional)

Instructions

If adding chicken, marinate the chicken with paprika, salt, and oil for 10-30 min. Lay out the sweet potato on one pan an the chickpeas on another. Lay the chicken on top of the sweet potato so as it cooks the juices are absorbed.

Preheat the oven to 400°F. Line a sheet pan with foil or parchment paper.

In a small bowl, toss the sweet potatoes with 2 tablespoons of the oil, the chili pow-der, and the salt. Spread the potatoes even-ly on the prepared sheet pan. In the same bowl, toss the chickpeas with the remaining 1 tablespoon olive oil, the garlic powder, and the paprika. Sprinkle the chickpeas over the potatoes so both are evenly distributed over

the sheet pan Roast until the sweet potatoes are cooked through and browtied and the thickpeas are crunchy 25 to 30 minutes, tosaing the potatoes and chickpeas mid-way through to roast evenly

Assemble the bowls: Divide the chopped kale evenly

among 4 bowls Spoon the sweet potatoes on top of the kale. Sprinkle the chickpeas evenly over the potatoes Drizzle a few tablespoons of the dressing over everything and garnish with sunflower seeds and fresh parsley or cilantro Serve with lime wedges for squeezing

Tahini Turmeric Lemon Dressing

Makes 1½ cups

Great for salads and drizzled over grilled chicken or veggies.

  • 1 cup tahini

  • 1/4 cup warm water

  • Juice of 1 lemon (3 tbs juice)

  • 3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil

  • 3 tablespoons maple syrup

  • 1 tablespoon ground turmeric

  • 1 teaspoon ground cumin

  • ½ teaspoon kosher salt, or more to taste

  • Freshly ground black pepper

In a medium bowl, whisk together the tahini, water, lern-on juice, olive ou, maple syrup, turmeric, cumin, salt, and a few twists of black pepper until smooth. If needed, add more water, a tablespoon at a time, until loose enough to drizzle. Use immediately, or store in a sealed container in the refrigerator for up to 4 days. You may need to swish in a tablespoon of warm water to loosen the dressing after refrigeration.

Lisa’s notes

This sauce is amazing!

item.title: Churro Chocodillas
item.dc:creator: Dirty Gourmet
item.description:
At a Glance

Serving Size: 1 chocodilla; Calories: 230; Protein: 4 g: Fat: 10 g: Satu-rated Fat: 7 g Carbohydrates: 31 g; Fiber: 2 g: Sugar: 15 g

Ingredients

2 tablespoons sugar

1½ teaspoons cinnamon

4 teaspoons coconut oil

4 (6-inch) flour tortillas

4 heaping tablespoons chocolate chips

TOOLS

Backcountry Base Kit

Skillet

Spatula

Instructions

One of my complaints about backpacking food is that it’s often mushy and served in a bowi-or, straight out of the pot. So, if I’m going to bother with making a dessert. I want it to include some texture and variety to counterbalance all the bowl meals These Churro Chocodillas are crispy on the outside and gooey on the inside, and they totally satisfy both my sweet tooth and my desire for variety on the trail -Aimee

AT HOME

Combine the sugar and cinnamon in a small ziplock bag

AT CAMP

Heat about 1 teaspoon of the oil in a skillet over high heat. Place a tortilla in the skillet and sprinkle half the tortilla with about 1 tablespoon of the chocolate chips. Fold over the tortilla and brown lightly on each side, about 2 minutes. Remove from heat and sprinkle with cinnamon-sugar mixture. Cut into a few triangles, and serve immediately. Repeat with the remaining tortillas.

Lisa’s notes

item.title: Thai Basil Chicken Bowls and Edamame Rice
item.dc:creator: Kylie Sakaida
item.link: https://questionable.quarto.pub/recipes/recipes/Thai Basil Chicken Bowls and Edamame Rice.html
item.description:
Ingredients

3 tablespoons reduced-sodium soy sauce

2 tablespoons oyster sauce

2 tablespoons light brown sugar

2 tablespoons canola oil

3 garlic cloves, minced

1 to 2 Thai chiles or 1 to 2 serrano peppers, seeded and finely chopped

1 medium shallot, halved and thinly sliced

1 pound ground chicken (see Note)

6 ounces green beans, trimmed and halved (about 2 cups)

1 red bell pepper, thinly sliced into strips

1 cup loosely packed fresh Thai basil leaves or Italian basil, thinly sliced

Steamed Rice (page 158), for serving

Instructions

In a small bowl, mix the soy sauce, oyster sauce, and brown sugar. Set aside.

Heat the oil in a large nonstick skillet over medium heat. When the oil is sizzling, add the garlic, chiles, and shallot, and cook, stirring frequently, until the shallot softens slightly, about 1 minute.

Add the ground chicken and cook, using a spoon to break it up into small bits, stirring occasionally, until it just begins to brown on the outside, about 3 minutes.

Add the green beans and bell pepper, cover, and cook, stirring occasionally, until the chicken is cooked through and the vegeta-bles are crisp-tender, 5 to 8 minutes.

Stir in the reserved sauce and cook until the sugar melts and the chicken is well coated, about 1 minute. Stir in the basil. Serve over rice.

Lisa’s notes

Mix Edamame into the rice for a meal with higher protein and fiber. Add some garlic chili sauce for crunch and deliciousness.
item.guid: https://questionable.quarto.pub/recipes/recipes/Thai Basil Chicken Bowls and Edamame Rice.html

media:content.url: https://questionable.quarto.pub/recipes/recipes/img/Thai Basil Chicken Bowls and Edamame Rice.jpg

item.title: Carrot cake in a bowl
item.dc:creator: https://trailcooking.com/
item.description:
Ingredients

  • 1⁄2 cup old-fashioned oats
  • 2 Tbsp diced dried carrots / or same grated carrots (the more carrots the better)
  • 3 Tbsp brown sugar
  • 2 Tbsp raisins
  • 2 Tbsp dry milk
  • 1⁄4 tsp ground cinnamon
  • Pinch fine sea salt
  • 2 Tbsp shredded coconut

Instructions

At home:

(Optional - do this to make it more “cake” like, or keep as is for more of an oatmeal experience) Whirl the oats in a blender until about ⅓ of the original size.

Put them in a quart freezer bag. Process the carrots in the same manner, adding them to the bag along with the other dry ingredients.

In camp:

Bring 1¼ cups water to a boil in your pot. Add the dry ingredients, stirring well, and bring back to a boil. Remove the pot from the stove, cover tightly, and let sit for 5 minutes. Stir well and top with coconut.

Notes:

For a less strong carrot taste, only use 1 Tablespoon. Use coconut, rice, or soy milk powder for a vegan version. This recipe was featured in the Washington Trails Magazine, January/February 2011 issue.

Lisa’s notes

At home I baked it for 15 min at 325 (the “reheat” setting) so the oats would cook a bit. This would be absolutely stellar camping.

item.title: Gnocchi with Sausage and Peppers
item.dc:creator: Kylie Sakaida from So Easy So Good
item.description:
Ingredients

12 ounces fully cooked sweet chicken sausages, cut into-inch pieces

1 (16-ounce) package gnocchi, shelf-stable or thawed / frozen

8 ounces mixed baby bell peppers, seeded and quartered (about 2 cups)

1 pint cherry tomatoes

3 garlic cloves, peeled but whole

Fresh rosemary sprigs

1 teaspoon Italian seasoning

Generous pinch of red pepper flakes, or more to taste

teaspoon kosher salt

Freshly ground black pepper

2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil

3 cups baby spinach

3 tablespoons grated Parmesan cheese

Instructions

Preheat the oven to 400°F

On a sheet pan, mix the sausages, gnocchi, bell peppers, tomatoes, garlic, rosemary, Italian seasoning, pepper flakes, salt, and

a few twists of black pepper Drizzle with the oil, toss well to combine, and spread the gnocchi and vegetables into one even layer

Bake for 12 minutes. Using a spatula, lift and turn all the ingredients to evenly cook. Return to the oven and cook until the sausages are golden brown, the gnocchi are plump and slightly golden, and the peppers are tender, about 15 minutes

To serve, evenly divide the spinach among 4 individual serving plates, top with the gnocchi/sausage mixture, and sprinkle with the Parmesan. If desired, garnish with chopped fresh parsley leaves or basil.

Lisa’s notes

Serve with arugula salad with a light drizzle of balsamic vinegar (and optionally, feta cheese). So good!

Jesse note: Do not get the chickpea gnocchi. I don’t know what to say about it…

item.title: Chinese steamed eggs
item.dc:creator: Kylie Sakaida
item.description:
At a Glance

Ingredients

2 large eggs, beaten

3/4 cup warm water or chicken broth

Kosher salt

2 teaspoons reduced-sodium soy sauce

1 teaspoon toasted sesame oil

1 scallion, thinly sliced

Instructions

In a medium bowl, combine the eggs, water, and a pinch of salt and whisk until combined.

Set a sieve over a 3-cup heatproof serving bowl. Pour the egg mixture evenly through the sieve to remove air bubbles. Cover with an inverted heatproof plate.

Place a steamer or a steamer rack in a pot and fill the pot with water until it reaches just below the rack. Cover and bring to a boil over high heat.

Reduce the heat to medium-low. Gently place the covered bowl in the steamer, cover the pot, and steam until solid yet still jiggly, about 12 minutes.

Carefully remove the bowl from the steamer. Garnish with soy sauce, sesame oil, and scallions. If desired, use a knife to cut through the surface of the curd in a cross-hatch design to allow the sauce to seep into the eggs.

Lisa’s notes

At elevation (5k feet) cooked for 13 min (rounding up, may have been closer to 14).

Added avocado on top and it was heavenly.

item.title: No bake breakfast cookies
item.dc:creator: Kylie Sakaida
item.description:
At a Glance

Serves 8

Total time: 10 minutes plus hour chilling time

GF, VG, VGN, DF

Ingredients

1/2 cup creamy peanut butter or almond butter (see Note)

2 tablespoons maple syrup or honey

1 cup old-fashioned rolled cats (gluten-free)

1/4 cup mix-ins: any combination of chopped nuts, dried cherries, chopped apricots, raisins, or pumpkin seeds

2 tablespoons chia seeds

2 tablespoons unsweetened coconut flakes

1 teaspoon vanilla extract

Instructions

Line a large plotter with parchment paper

In a large microwaves safe bowl, combine the peanut butter and maple syrup or honey) and microwave for 20 seconds/ warm up in the toaster oven. Stir the mixture until smooth. Add the oats, mix-ins, chia seeds, coconut flakes, and vanilla extract and stir until combined.

Divide the dough into & equal portions and roll into balls. Place the balls on the parchment paper. Using your palm, gently press to flatten the balls and top with the coconut flakes. Refrigerate until well chilled, about 1 hour.

Refrigerate in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks. They’re best about 5 minutes out of the fridge and yummy on the go.

Lisa’s notes

item.title: Meat sauce (and collared greens)
item.dc:creator: Jesse Frey
item.description:
Ingredients

  • Italian sausage 2 lbs
  • Get two jars of red pasta sauce (basil and garlic is good)
  • 2 carrots
  • 2 peppers (Anaheim, poblano both good)
  • 1 box of noodles (12 oz, we like the Jovial bow tie)
  • Collared greens 2 bunches
  • 2-4 cloves of garlic
  • Olive oil
  • Salt
  • Pepper

Instructions

Cook noodles according to directions

When noodles are done, rinse under cold water and add some old when transferring back to pan so they don’t clump.

Cut the collared greens so that the stems and leaves are separate

Finely minced garlic

Cook the stems and the garlic together until somewhat soft

Add leaves (shredded so they are small)

Cook until leaves are wilted but not soggy (I want to chew my food)

Cut carrots and peppers

Brown the meat

Add the carrots and let go for a little while

Add peppers and sauce

Let simmer until delicious

Serve with love

item.title: Jesse’s Corn Bread
item.dc:creator: Jesse Frey
item.description:
• 1 c masa ca (tortilla corn flour)
  • 1 c regular corn meal
  • 2 tsp baking powder
  • 1 tsp baking soda
  • 1/2 tsp salt
  • 1 TBS vinegar mixed with milk (1 c)
  • 1/4 c oil
  • 2 eggs

Instructions

  1. Mix everything together
  2. Cook in warmed cast iron at 400f for 20min (once a toothpick in the middle is clean)

Lisa’s notes

item.title: Curry chicken salad
item.dc:creator: Carolyn Ketchum
item.description:
At a Glance

Cuisine Indian

Keyword curried chicken salad, keto chicken salad

Prep Time 10minutes minutes

Total Time 10minutes minutes

Servings 4 servings

Calories 376kcal

Nutrition

Serving: 1cup (approximately) | Calories: 376kcal | Carbohydrates: 4.4g | Protein: 34g | Fat: 23.4g | Fiber: 3g

Ingredients

  • 1 1/2 lb cooked chicken diced (1 rotisserie chicken)
  • 2 ribs celery chopped
  • 1/2 medium red pepper chopped
  • 1/4 cup roasted chopped pecans
  • 1/3 cup mayonnaise
  • 1 to 2 tbsp curry powder
  • 3/4 tsp salt
  • 1/2 tsp pepper
  • 1/8 tsp cayenne optional

Instructions

  1. Place the chicken, celery, red pepper, and pecans in a bowl and toss to combine.
  2. Add the mayonnaise, curry powder, salt, pepper, and cayenne and stir until well coated. Refrigerate until chilled.

Lisa’s notes

Use inside a burrito with some lettuce, as a topping on crackers or cucumbers, added to salads, etc.

item.title: Coconut rice bowls
item.dc:creator: Dirty Gourmet, Aimee
item.description:
Ingredients

  • 1 1/2 cups jasmine rice
  • 1 14-ounce can full fat coconut milk about 2 cups plus 1/3 cup water
  • 1 teaspoon salt
  • 2 red bell peppers, chopped
  • 1 cucumber, chopped
  • 2 carrots, chopped
  • 4 green onions, sliced
  • 1 cup roasted cashews
  • 1/2 cup peanut butter
  • 2 limes, juiced (4 tbs lime juice)
  • 2 tablespoons soy sauce
  • 2 teaspoons brown sugar
  • 2 teaspoons siracha

Instructions

  1. Rinse the rice well, until water no longer looks starchy. Drain well.
  2. Open the can of coconut milk and scoop out the thick later of coconut cream, setting it aside. Pour the remaining coconut water in a large liquid measuring cup. Add enough water to the coconut water to measure 2 1/2 cups.
  3. In a large pot, combine the coconut water and water mixture with the rice and salt. Bring to a boil over high heat. Reduce heat to low and simmer, covered, for about 15 minutes. Stir once during that 15 minutes. Remove from heat and stir in the reserved coconut cream. Transfer to a large bowl to cool.
  4. Meanwhile, make the dressing. Combine peanut butter, water, lime juice, soy sauce, brown sugar and sriracha in a medium bowl. Whisk well. You may need to add a little more water to thin if desired. Taste and adjust seasonings.
  5. Once the rice is cool, add the bell peppers, cucumber, carrots, green onions and cashews.
  6. Serve drizzled with the peanut dressing.

Lisa’s notes

Reserving 1/4 c from the can of melted coconut milk also worked, though I’m sure the method as written would be even better.

Add chicken (pan seared with soy sauce) to add some more protein if desired.

item.title: General Tso’s Tofu with Quinoa & Broccoli
item.dc:creator: Purple Carrot
item.description:
Ingredients

  • 1 oz ginger, peeled and minced
  • 2 garlic cloves, peeled and minced
  • 2 tsp brown sugar
  • 3 tbsp low-sodium tamari
  • 1 tbsp seasoned rice vinegar
  • 10 oz organic extra firm tofu, patted dry and cut into 1/2-inch cubes
  • 1/4 cup cornstarch
  • 1 tbsp tuxedo sesame seeds (divided)
  • 2 scallions, trimmed and cut into 2-inch pieces
  • 6 oz broccoli florets
  • 6 oz precooked golden quinoa
  • 2 tbsp vegetable oil
  • Salt
  • Pepper

Instructions

Cooking Quinoa: do a 1 3/4 c ratio of water: 1 c Quinoa

1 Make the sauce Bring large pot of salted water to a boil for broccoli. Whisk together ginger, garlic, tamari, sugar, and vinegar in medium bowl.

2 Crisp the tofu Combine tofu, cornstarch, just 2 tsp sesame seeds, and a pinch of salt and pepper in large bowl and toss to coat. Heat 2 tbsp vegetable oil in large nonstick skillet over medium-high heat. Add coated tofu and cook, tossing occasionally, until crispy and browned in places, 5 to 8 minutes.

3 Finish the tofu Add scallion to skillet with tofu and cook until softened, 1 to 2 minutes. Reduce heat to low, add sauce, and toss. Cook until sauce thickens, about 30 seconds.

4 Cook the broccoli and warm the quinoa Add broccoli to boiling water and cook until tender and bright green, 2 to 3 minutes. Drain and add a pinch of salt and pepper. Make small tear at top of quinoa bag and microwave for 60 seconds. (TIP: You can also combine precooked quinoa and 1 tbsp water in small saucepan over medium-high heat. Cover and steam until warmed through, 3 to 4 minutes.)

5 Serve Divide warmed quinoa and cooked broccoli between large plates and top with General Tso’s tofu. Sprinkle with remaining sesame seeds.

Lisa’s notes

The sugar seemed too high, and the soy sauce too low so we swapped them and it was great.

Double the recipe to have leftovers for the next day.
